case_id: State of U.P. v. Pappu (2005) 3 SCC 594
facts: Incident occurred on October 16, 1979, at about 6:00 PM near village Saidham.
Allegation: Pappu @ Suresh Chand (Respondent-Accused), along with co-accused Nanhey, Dharampal, and Khacheru, attacked Ram Kumar (deceased) and his brother Ramesh Chand (PW-1) due to a land dispute.
Weapons allegedly used: Pappu and Nanhey used knives (chhuri); Dharampal and Khacheru used lathis.
Ram Kumar sustained knife injuries attributed to Pappu and Nanhey, and lathi injuries attributed to Dharampal and Khacheru. He died as a result.
Ramesh Chand (PW-1) sustained knife injuries attributed to Pappu and Nanhey.
First Information Report (FIR) was lodged promptly by Ramesh Chand (PW-1) at PS Kharkhoda on the same day (16.10.1979) at 7:15 PM.
Medical Examination: Dr. M.K. Jain (PW-6) examined Ramesh Chand (PW-1) on 16.10.1979 at 9:30 PM, noting incised wounds.

Autopsy: Dr. K.C. Gupta (PW-5) conducted the post-mortem on Ram Kumar's body on 17.10.1979, finding incised wounds and contusions. Cause of death was opined as shock and haemorrhage due to ante-mortem injuries.
Eyewitnesses: Prosecution relied on Ramesh Chand (PW-1, injured eyewitness), Babu Khan (PW-2), and Mahendra Singh (PW-3).

Trial Court: Convicted all four accused under Section 302 read with Section 34 IPC (sentenced to life imprisonment) and Section 324 read with Section 34 IPC (sentenced to 2 years RI). Sentences to run concurrently.

High Court: Allowed the appeal filed by the accused and acquitted all of them. Reasons for acquittal included: Doubts about the presence of PW-2 and PW-3 at the scene, finding their testimony unreliable; discrepancies in evidence; delay in the FIR copy reaching the Magistrate.
Supreme Court: State of U.P. filed an appeal against the High Court's acquittal, specifically challenging the acquittal of Pappu @ Suresh Chand.
ipc_sections: Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means)
Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in acquitting the accused, particularly Pappu, by discarding the credible and consistent testimony of the injured eyewitness (PW-1) and other eyewitnesses (PW-2, PW-3), which was fully corroborated by medical evidence.
precedents: State of U.P. v. Kishan Chand (2004) 7 SCC 629 (Weightage to injured eyewitness testimony)
Jarnail Singh v. State of Punjab (2009) 9 SCC 719 (Credibility of injured witness is generally higher)
Abdul Sayeed v. State of M.P. (2010) 10 SCC 259 (Testimony of injured witness has special status)
elements: Presence of eyewitnesses at the scene
Credibility and consistency of PW-1, PW-2, PW-3 testimonies regarding Pappu's role
Corroboration between ocular evidence and medical evidence (PW-5, PW-6 reports)
Existence of common intention (Section 34) among the accused

counter_arguments.loophole: Minor discrepancies and contradictions existed in the statements of PW-1, PW-2, and PW-3, which the High Court found significant enough to doubt their veracity and presence.
supporting_precedents: State of Rajasthan v. Raja Ram (2003) 8 SCC 180 (Serious contradictions can render testimony unreliable)
Supt. of Police, CBI v. G.S. Saran (2011) 13 SCC 558 (Benefit of doubt arises from material contradictions)
Lallu Manjhi v. State of Jharkhand (2003) 2 SCC 401 (Need for careful scrutiny of related or chance witnesses)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court gave undue importance to minor inconsistencies and the alleged delay in the FIR reaching the magistrate, ignoring established legal principles that minor discrepancies do not vitiate credible testimony and procedural delays must be shown to cause prejudice.
precedents: Leela Ram v. State of Haryana (1999) 9 SCC 525 (Minor variations do not affect core case)
State of U.P. v. M.K. Anthony (1985) 1 SCC 505 (Discrepancies should not be over-emphasized if substance is consistent)
Meharaj Singh v. State of U.P. (1994) 5 SCC 188 (Delay in FIR dispatch not fatal unless prejudice shown)
elements: Naturalness of minor discrepancies in testimony
Lack of prejudice caused by FIR dispatch delay
Sufficiency of explanation for any delay (if provided)

counter_arguments.loophole: The delay in the FIR reaching the concerned Magistrate (raised by the High Court) could potentially indicate deliberation or manipulation before the official recording, casting doubt on its spontaneity.
supporting_precedents: Thulia Kali v. State of Tamil Nadu (1972) 3 SCC 393 (Unexplained delay in FIR raises suspicion)
Marudanal Augusti v. State of Kerala (1980) 4 SCC 425 (Delay needs satisfactory explanation)
Ram Jag v. State of U.P. (1974) 4 SCC 201 (Delay can be a factor suggesting concoction)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court's decision constituted perverse appreciation of evidence, justifying interference in an appeal against acquittal. The trial court's assessment was well-reasoned and based on sound evidence.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles for appeal against acquittal; interference if judgment is perverse)
State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup (1974) 4 SCC 764 (Appellate court can re-appreciate evidence in appeal against acquittal)
Allarakha K. Mansuri v. State of Gujarat (2002) 3 SCC 57 (Interference warranted if acquittal leads to miscarriage of justice)
elements: Demonstration that High Court's findings were unreasonable or ignored compelling evidence
Soundness of the Trial Court's reasoning and conviction
Presence of overwhelming evidence pointing towards guilt

counter_arguments.loophole: Appellate courts should be slow to interfere with acquittals, especially if the view taken by the High Court is a possible view based on the evidence, even if another view exists.
supporting_precedents: Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154 (High threshold for reversing acquittal)
Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225 (Acquittal not to be reversed lightly)
Ajit Savant Majagavi v. State of Karnataka (1997) 7 SCC 110 (Presumption of innocence reinforced by acquittal)

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly acquitted the accused as the prosecution case suffered from material contradictions, unreliable witnesses (PW-2, PW-3), and procedural infirmities (FIR delay), creating reasonable doubt.
edge_cases: Reliability of chance witnesses (PW-2, PW-3) without independent corroboration.
Impact of delay in FIR reaching magistrate under Section 157 CrPC.
Potential for false implication due to pre-existing land dispute.
precedents: Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras AIR 1957 SC 614 (Classification and reliability of witnesses)
State of Haryana v. Ram Singh (2002) 2 SCC 426 (Need for caution when witnesses are partisan or interested)
Rajeevan v. State of Kerala (2003) 3 SCC 355 (Material contradictions creating doubt)

defense_arguments.argument: The presence of PW-2 and PW-3 at the scene was highly doubtful, as noted by the High Court. Their testimonies lacked credibility and were inconsistent.
edge_cases: Lack of blood stains on clothes of alleged eyewitnesses PW-2/PW-3.
Delay in police examination of PW-2/PW-3.
Inconsistencies regarding sequence of events and specific roles.
precedents: Kansa Behera v. State of Orissa AIR 1987 SC 1507 (Doubtful presence of eyewitnesses)
Balaka Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1975 SC 1962 (Effect of embellishments and improvements by witnesses)
Bihari Nath v. State of M.P. (1997) 1 Crimes 161 (SC) (Mentioned in secondary sources regarding witness presence, requires verification)

defense_arguments.argument: Common intention under Section 34 IPC was not conclusively established, especially for the specific act causing death. Each accused should be liable only for their individual acts, if proven.
edge_cases: Distinguishing between common intention and similar intention.
Requirement of pre-arranged plan or meeting of minds immediately before/during the act.
precedents: Suresh v. State of U.P. (2001) 3 SCC 673 (Distinction between common intention and similar intention)
Dajabhai Chagganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat AIR 1964 SC 1563 (Common intention requires prior meeting of minds)
Mahboob Shah v. Emperor AIR 1945 PC 118 (Landmark case defining common intention)

judgment.outcome: Appeal Allowed. The Supreme Court set aside the High Court's judgment acquitting Pappu @ Suresh Chand and restored the Trial Court's judgment convicting him under Section 302/34 IPC and Section 324/34 IPC and the sentences imposed.
reasoning: The High Court's reasons for acquittal were found to be 'flimsy and perverse'.
The testimony of the injured eyewitness, Ramesh Chand (PW-1), was consistent, credible, and inspired confidence. His presence was natural and his account was corroborated by medical evidence.
Established principle that testimony of an injured witness is accorded high reliability unless strong reasons exist to discard it.
Minor discrepancies in testimonies of PW-1, PW-2, and PW-3 were natural and did not affect the core prosecution case or PW-1's credibility.
The High Court wrongly discarded PW-2 and PW-3's testimonies based on minor points; their presence was plausible.
The delay in the FIR copy reaching the Magistrate was explained (due to distance and process) and not fatal to the prosecution case, as no prejudice was shown.
Medical evidence (PW-5, PW-6) fully corroborated the ocular account regarding the nature and location of injuries inflicted by knives and lathis.
Common intention (Section 34) was clearly applicable to Pappu, given his active participation in the attack with a knife along with others using weapons, targeting the deceased and PW-1.

The High Court failed to apply the correct principles for appreciating eyewitness testimony, especially that of an injured witness, and interfered with the trial court's findings on untenable grounds.
cited_cases: State of U.P. v. Anil Singh AIR 1988 SC 1998 (Reliability of eyewitness testimony, minor discrepancies)
Rammi alias Rameshwar v. State of M.P. AIR 1999 SC 3544 (Principles for appreciating evidence in criminal trials)
State of Rajasthan v. Kalki AIR 1981 SC 1390 (Credibility of witnesses)
Appabhai v. State of Gujarat AIR 1988 SC 696 (Minor discrepancies in witness statements)
State of H.P. v. Mast Ram AIR 2004 SC 5056 (Delay in FIR dispatch to magistrate)
Anil Rai v. State of Bihar (2001) 7 SCC 318 (Delay in FIR reaching court)
Mohar v. State of U.P. (2002) 7 SCC 606 (Testimony of injured witness)
Krishnan v. State represented by Inspector of Police (2003) 7 SCC 56 (Weightage to injured witness)
Ram Swaroop v. State of U.P. AIR 2000 SC 715 (Common Intention - Section 34 IPC)

Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Cited retrospectively as it aligns with the principles applied regarding appeal against acquittal - though decided later, the principles were established earlier).
